review.title: Automatic Extraction of Causal Relations from Natural Language Texts: A Comprehensive Survey
review.abstract: Automatic extraction of cause-effect relationships from natural language texts is a challenging open problem in Artificial Intelligence. Most of the early attempts at its solution used manually constructed linguistic and syntactic rules on small and domain-specific data sets. However, with the advent of big data, the availability of affordable computing power and the recent popularization of machine learning, the paradigm to tackle this problem has slowly shifted. Machines are now expected to learn generic causal extraction rules from labelled data with minimal supervision, in a domain independent-manner. In this paper, we provide a comprehensive survey of causal relation extraction techniques from both paradigms, and analyse their relative strengths and weaknesses, with recommendations for future work.

sections.heading: III. STATISTICAL & MACHINE LEARNING TECHNIQUES
sections.text: The need to use a large amount of labeled, domain and type-independent text data and automatically extract implicit patterns in the text meant that machine learning techniques could potentially do much better than purely linguistic techniques. Thus, since the early 2000s, the paradigm for solving the problem of automatic causal extraction has shifted to statistics and machine learning. The early studies relied on explicitly labeled cause-and-effect pairs in sentences, but over time, researchers began to consider implicit and ambiguous constructs through careful feature extraction.

sections.heading: V. CONCLUSION & FUTURE WORK
sections.text: In this paper, we have provided a comprehensive review of the research literature of the past three decades on the automatic extraction of causal relationships from the two paradigms of non-statistical and statistical techniques. In addition, we offer an in-depth discussion of at least five highly cited research studies from both paradigms. We observe that the extraction of causal relationships is one of the most difficult NLP issues, primarily due to the presence of implicit linguistic constructs that may or may not be causal depending on the textual context. Data sparseness is another problem for highly specialized areas where expert annotation is required, making it difficult to use minimally monitored techniques for this problem. By using advanced feature construction techniques, lexico-semantic resources such as WordNet, and powerful learning algorithms such as SVMs, the machine learning community is able to achieve reasonably good results in recent years.

metadata.abstractText: Automatic extraction of cause-effect relationships from natural language texts is a challenging open problem in Artificial Intelligence. Most of the early attempts at its solution used manually constructed linguistic and syntactic rules on small and domain-specific data sets. However, with the advent of big data, the availability of affordable computing power and the recent popularization of machine learning, the paradigm to tackle this problem has slowly shifted. Machines are now expected to learn generic causal extraction rules from labelled data with minimal supervision, in a domain independent-manner. In this paper, we provide a comprehensive survey of causal relation extraction techniques from both paradigms, and analyse their relative strengths and weaknesses, with recommendations for future work. Keywords—Causality Extraction, Causal Knowledge, Causal Relations, Natural Language Processing, Machine Learning, Computational Linguistics, Information Retrieval, Survey
